Voucher No. 122

DATE May 6, 1946
Dear Mr. Phelan,

In a recent conversation with Rev. Nathan Dwyer he told me that the coke-oil system of heating was most unsatisfactory in schools. He had tried it out last year. He strongly advised hard coal as being cheaper and more convenient than wood.

The coal stoves would cost about twenty-four dollars each and one for the living room would cost about twelve dollars. The kitchen stove is made to burn wood or coal. He estimated about two or at most three tons of hard coal would be sufficient for the year. This would eliminate all the splitting, piling, cutting etc., that goes along with the wood system. I do hope you will give it every consideration. I have not spoken the agent yet. He gave me a telephone call.
Yesterday but I was away and I believe he is out of town now. I would be obliged if you could send me some forms for the monthly report re. absences and some forms for application to enter Spanish School.

The scout movement has certainly been successful. The boys are intensely interested. They have their scout kit and softball diamond and teams chosen. Today the Blessed Sacrament Sacred Heart Parish came to visit us and they just announced that the score was 17-18 in favour of the South, but the King's Scout told me our boys were good players. They seem to favour softball. Later they had a boxing match in Miss MacNeil's class-room. Fortunately for them they are in the South, but I feel they have everything cleaned in scout fashion.

If you see Mr. Smith I could speak of this matter but I trust we may be able to procure the coal.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Ottawa, May 9, 1946.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Since writing to you on the 6th instant, with reference to the possibility of using oil heating in the Garden River R.C. School, it occurred to me that it might be preferable to use coal. Coal stoves would be cheaper and the cost of operation would probably be about the same as the oil. You might also obtain quotations on the coal stoves that would be needed and let me have an estimate of the number of tons of coal that would be required.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES.

With reference to your letter file 13-3-5 dated 9th May 1946, regarding the using of coal at the Garden River R.C. School, I am enclosing herewith quotations received from Greenwoods Hardware, Sault Ste. Marie, on coal stoves.

The estimated number of tons of coal required would be 16 tons of Pecahontas.

It would also cost approximately $50.00 to replace the present wood sheds with a satisfactory coal bin.

To date I have been unable to receive quotations on crude oil stoves, but will forward same as soon as I receive them.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.
Ottawa, June 5, 1946.

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

I have your letter of the last instant, with reference to the Garden River R.C. School.

You may purchase two of the Quebec heaters, No. 165, large, for the classrooms. You should also secure a smaller size coal stove for the teacher's living room.

As it will be necessary to purchase coal for the kitchen range, I suppose you will require coal of different sizes. Please let me know the number of tons of each size that you think will be needed.

Approval is granted for the expenditure of $50.00 to provide a satisfactory coal-bin.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Further to our letter file 1-39-1 dated 1st June 1946, I am listing below quotations received from Kleiman Bros., Sault Ste. Marie, for oil heaters for the Garden River R.C. School.

Large Norge Oil Heater .................. $159.50 - 2 required
Medium Norge Oil Heater ................. $134.50
Small Norge Heater ....... $85.00 to $89.00 at present hard to obtain. 1 would be required.

Approximate cost of 250 gallon tanks.... $40.00 two would be required.
Cost of copper tubing 12¢ per ft.
About 60 ft. required.
Approximate cost of stands for tanks ....$10.00 two required.

R.P.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Would you be able to inform us if there is any possibility of a furnace being installed here before long? The suggested improvements were approved, with the exception of some form of central heating.

We use five stoves—one in each classroom and three in the teacherage. Two bedrooms and the bathroom have no heat. Last fall we had a grate put in the hallways outside these rooms to permit heat from the kitchen to reach them and although it was not too uncomfortable due to mild winter weather, it is not conducive to good health.

The classrooms are not fully heated by the stoves which we light ourselves in the morning as no person is available for such work in the winter time.

I am aware of the difficulty of planning for a furnace since the building is on swampy ground, but perhaps someone can devise a more efficient and less laborious heating system.

Sister Alice Marie

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

There will be eight children of school age, members of the Batchewana Band of Indians, whose parents have moved from the Garden River Reserve to the Rankin Location (New Batchewana Reserve), who will require schooling this fall.

Most of the above children have been attending the Garden River R.C. School in the past, and they can still do so, provided they are supplied with transportation.

I have taken the matter of transportation up with Mr. F.J. Redmond, manager of the Algoma Steel Corporation Bus System, and am enclosing for your information correspondence regarding same.

You will note that Mr. Redmond states that they could extend the present bus service to Garden River, provided there will be at least ten passengers to be picked up. That would be a minimum charge of $2.00 per school day. Although there are only eight children at present, this number is sure to increase in the near future, as more members of the Batchewana Band move off the Garden River Reserve to the Rankin Location, and the present pre-school children on the Location reach school age.

We have a two room school (R.C.) at the Garden River Reserve, and by transporting these children back to the school they previously attended, would keep the attendance of this Indian day school up. Kindly advise me regarding this matter at your earliest convenience.

R.P.G. Laurence
Supt. Indian Agency
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario
August 1, 1949.

Mr. F. J. Redmond,
Manager,
Algoma Steel Corporation Bus System,
51 Dennis Street,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

A number of Indian children who live on the Rankin Location on the north side of Highway #17 will require transportation to the R.C. School at Garden River this fall.

I understand you have a school bus that runs as far as Bell's Point each school day transporting white children to the City schools and returning them in the evening. Could an arrangement be made to have this bus continue along Highway 17 to the R.C. School on the Garden River Reserve picking up Indian children on its way east and taking them to this school? On its return trip in the evening with the white children, it could again continue as far as the Garden River School and bring the Indian children back to the Rankin Location.

There would be at this time about 10 children to pick up at the Rankin, but I expect this number will increase in the near future.

Would you kindly advise me, at your earliest convenience, how much you would charge for this service, as I wish to take this matter up with the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa and have some arrangement made before the opening of the coming school term.

Yours truly,

R. P. G. Laurence,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
Mr. R. P. G. Laurence,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Ottawa, September 26, 1923.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to state that the residence in use by the teachers of the Indian Day School used by the Roman Catholic portion of the Garden River and Batchawana Indians and situated on the Garden River Indian reserve, in the district of Algoma in the province of Ontario, is inadequate and so dilapidated as to be beyond repair, and it is necessary to replace the same at a cost estimated at $2000.00 for a suitable four-roomed cottage to accommodate the two teachers employed.

The capital at the credit of the Garden River and Batchawana bands amounts respectively to $97,822.88 and $87,117.51, and it is proposed to meet the cost of the new building from their funds in proportion to the number of children attending the school from the two bands, namely, $1500.00 from the Garden River band and $500.00 from the Batchawana band.

The undersigned would accordingly recommend that, under Section 89 of the Indian Act, the authority of Your Excellency in Council be given for the above mentioned expenditures of $1500.00 and $500.00 being made from the Garden River and Batchawana capital accounts, respectively, on the construction of the teachers' residence referred to.

INDIAN AFFAIRS -

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Honourable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs reporting that the residence in use by the teachers of the Indian Day School used by the Roman Catholic portion of the Garden River and Batchawana Indians and situated on the Garden River Indian reserve, in the district of Algoma in the province of Ontario, is inadequate and so dilapidated as to be beyond repair, and it is necessary to replace the same at a cost estimated at $2,000.00 for a suitable four-roomed cottage to accommodate the two teachers employed; that the capital at the credit of the Garden River and Batchawana bands amounts respectively to $5,822.85 and $67,117.51, and it is proposed to meet the cost of the new building from their funds in proportion to the number of children attending the school from the two bands, namely, $1,500.00 from the Garden River band and $500.00 from the Batchawana band.

ing, room furniture, and smaller

age. Hence the extra expenses. I told

Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

As you have already been advised, it is our intention to engage two Sisters of St. Joseph to take charge of the Garden River R.C. School for the coming academic year.

The Sisters desire to have the living quarters enlarged and we are prepared to have this done. We have been informed that the following firms might be interested in building an addition:

Mr. Carl Fitzpatrick, 780 Wellington E., Sault Ste. Marie.

Mr. J.J. Fitzpatrick, & Son, 27 Towers,

McLarty Bros. & Brodie, 11 Gouin,

We would appreciate it if you would give the matter your immediate attention and let us know what can be done to enlarge the living quarters.

Is there a hydro line passing the school and would it cost to install electricity?

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PP/MOD
Mr. R.P.G. Laurence, Indian Agent, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,

As promised you last week, enclosed please find a sketch of the suggested changes to be made at the Garden River H.C., Indian Day School.

This addition should be well insulated and be excavated. The window in the foundation that would be covered by this addition should be knocked out and a door installed. In the floor, provision should be made for a sump pump. I would suggest that ducts for a central heating be put in the walls at the time of construction.

The division between the present kitchen and the new one could be left as is or could be changed into an archway. The Contractor will give you his opinion of this part of the work.

The windows on the south bedroom will have to be moved to the west and east wall.

Should the Contractor suggest any other changes you will kindly advise us.

The Department intends to have the portion below the teacher's living-room excavated and have a central heating system installed. You might get an estimate of the cost of this improvement and notify us at your earliest convenience.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

This would make the new extension 15 x 15 instead of 12 x 15 as the size of the new kitchen would remain the same as per your sketch.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Garden River R.C. Indian Day School,
Sault Ste. Marie Indian Agency,
Electoral District of Algoma West.

The Sisters who have been in charge of this school for several years gave up duties at the end of June and we were obliged to secure another Order, namely the Sisters of St. Joseph.

There are two Sisters employed as teachers and in addition they have another Sister as housekeeper. The living accommodation is too small and some repairs are necessary. Mr. Doucet of this Branch visited this school during the latter part of August and recommends an addition to the building as well as improvements to the heating and water systems.

The Indian Agent has secured a quotation from George V. Hannah, General Contractor, Sault Ste. Marie, who is prepared to do the necessary work immediately at a cost not exceeding $3,500.

Funds for the purpose are available in the current year's appropriation and I would appreciate it if you would give the necessary authority for us to authorize Mr. Hannah to proceed with the work that we consider necessary at the price mentioned above.

Director.

The Department finds it necessary to return your voucher No. 1377. When we wrote to you on October 25, we were under the impression that we could make interim payments for the work being done by Mr. Hannah at the Garden River School. However, we are now advised that Treasury regulations will not permit progress payments on a flat contract price. On work done on a cost plus basis (such as at the Mississauga Day School) we can make progress payments. However, Treasury regulations do not permit any payment being made on a flat contract price until the work is entirely completed and we can then certify that the contract has been carried out in the manner required. As it is presumed that this work will now have been completed by Mr. Hannah, if you will forward the final accounts we will endeavour to have an immediate payment made of the whole amount due.

Ottawa, October 23, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Agent Cockburn forwards a letter from Chief Goulais, of the Nipissing band, with the names of other Indians attached, asking for the removal of Mr. Le Tenturier, teacher of the Garden Indian Village school. The Indians state that unless they get a new teacher they will not send their children to school.

Since last July some of the Indians have been dissatisfied with the teacher, complaining that he has made himself disagreeable to them as a resident on the reserve. The Department has never been able to find out in what way Mr. Le Tenturier has antagonized the Indians, but he was warned to try to get along with them as harmoniously as possible and he wrote assuring the Department that he would do all in his power to carry out its wishes. There is nothing on file to show that the Chief and Indians have been willing to meet him half way and they seem bent to get rid of him.

There is no doubt about his being a competent teacher, judging from the Inspector's reports and as he is
is a married man with a very large family it would be a hardship to dismiss him summarily to meet the whims of the Indians. Mr. Le Tonturier's letters show that he is somewhat of a "crank", but there is some excuse for a man with a wife and twelve children who has to support them on $350.00 a year.

It might be well to give them a new teacher but the present one should have ample time given him to look out for other employment, and I would recommend that Mr. Agent Cockburn be instructed to advise the Indians that no change can be made until the end of the present school year and that if they take their children away from school they will be proceeded against under the regulations for the compulsory attendance of Indian children. He should also advise Mr. Le Tonturier that the Department has decided in the interests of all concerned to make a change of teacher in this school after June 30, next, but if he can better himself in the meantime he will be at liberty to do so upon giving reasonable notice.

This teacher has good control but her methods develop the written work rather than the language faculty through oral instruction. Teaching should be done orally. The pupils are taught to read (?) before they know what they are saying.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Agent Cockburn, who called at the Department today, thinks that it would be advisable to notify Mrs. Ladouceur teacher of the Garden Village School, that her services will not be required after the 30th of June next, as the Indians are dissatisfied with her and she is not a successful teacher.

Mr. Cockburn states that this school is deserving of a good teacher and that, if we wish to get one, we will have to provide living quarters. He considers that a two roomed frame bungalow, painted would be suitable. Mr. Cockburn states that there is room on the school lot for such a building and that there are Indians on the reserve who could put up a suitable house, which should not cost more than $500.00.

A frame building, 12' by 16' to be divided by a wooden partition into a bedroom 7' by 12' and a living room 9' by 12' would give ample accommodation. Mr. Cockburn informed me that the furniture in the teacher's residence at the Nipissing School, which has been closed for some time would be available.

The Nipissing Band have $117,248.93 to the credit of their capital account and could easily stand the expenditure.

If you approved of Mr. Cockburn's recommendation he is prepared to furnish an estimate of the necessary material.

Martin Benson.

Specifications for the erection of proposed Indian School-House and Out-Buildings, and the laying out of the School Grounds at

Description:-

The school house building is to be a one story frame structure on a stone foundation built in accordance with the accompanying drawings.

Foundation:-

Dig a trench (see plan of grounds for the location of the building) to receive the foundation for the walls of the school-room, cloak-room and shed, two feet deep and two feet wide, and hand lay a dry wall 20 inches thick to the level of the ground, upon this wall build with fair sized building stones a mason wall, well bonded, 18 inches high and not less than 16 inches thick.

Dig three pits 2 X 2 X 2 feet deep and at seven feet centres, as shown on the plan and build piers in a similar manner to the walls.

The earth is to be well rammed against the walls and piers to ground level.

Ventilators:-

Provide and place five common iron ventilators in the outside walls of the building, three on the southerly and two on the front elevation.

Chimney:-

The footing stone of the chimney is to be 6 inches thick. Build chimney of hard burnt brick and cement mortar, full joint. Brick to commence at top of mason wall. Build in the chimney from bottom to top a 12 inch diameter, 1/16 inch thick galvanized iron smoke stack, to be securely jointed together, and held to the side of the chimney shaft. The bottom of the smoke stack is to empty into a soot box, which is to be provided with a door opening say 18 inches above
Chimney:- above the floor, on the cloak room side of the chimney.

Provide and place a large ventilating register, at least two feet square on surface, on the school-room side of the chimney at the bottom of the wainscoting.

Put in thimble and stopper for stove pipe.

Sills, Joists:- Wall plates 2 X 8 inches well bedded with mortar. Girder under centre of floor 6 X 8 inches; floor joists 2 X 10 inches at 16 inch centres. Put two rows of herring bone bridging of 2 X 2 inch stuff, well nailed between the outside walls and the centre girder.

Walls:- The studding to be 2 X 4 inch stuff doubled at the corners, and windows and door frames, well braced with two rows of braces. Wall plates double 2 X 4 inches, and double over window and door openings.

The outside of walls to be first sheeted on the outside with 1 inch rough boards, put on diagonally close jointed and well nailed, and fitted closely to the windows and door frames; and then to be sheeted with 1 inch clapboards 5 inches wide, one ply of 12 oz. tar paper, well lapped, is to be laid between the above sheeting and clapboards.

The inside of the out walls of the shed is to be rough boarded.

Roofing:- The rafters are to be 2 X 6 inch at 3 feet centres. Hip rafters 2 X 7 inches. The rafters of the cloak room and shed are to be 2 X 5 inches, 3 feet centres. The tie beams of the roof to be 2 X 6 inch, and 16 feet long, 3 feet centres. Belfry roof rafters 2 X 4 inch. All rafters to be properly framed and well spiked down.

Cover the several roofs with rough boarding closely laid and well nailed to the rafters, and lay one ply
Roofing:-
ply of heavy tar paper over same, well lapped, and shingle with best sawn cedar shingles, dipped in Cabot's light moss green stain, Creonte Shingle Stain (Seymour & Co., Montreal) 4 1/2" to the weather, finish roof with weather boards and roll complete. Lay tar paper under the eaves before sheeting.

Wainscoting:-
The walls of the school-room are to be wainscoted, 3'-6" high with narrow beaded sheeting. Finish with cap and Scotia and put quarter round at the floor. The walls of the cloak-room are to be wainscoted to a height of 6 feet.

Doors and Windows:-
Provide and hang with 3 - 4 inch butts the four doors shown on the plan. Inside doors to be four panelled 1 3/4" thick, 7' high and 4' wide. To have rebated frames 2 1/8" thick. Provide and fix best G" American locks to entrance and school-room doors, with two keys to each, and suitable furniture. Shed door to have outside good padlock and hook inside. Put 7/8" thick oak thresholds at all outside doors and school room door. The windows will be of the size and number shown on the plan. The frames to be fitted with 1 3/4" pine double sliding lip sash hung and properly balanced with weights and heavy Silver Lake Sash cord.

The whole of the windows to be fitted with 1 1/2" winter sashes. Winter sashes to be divided into same number of lights as permanent sash with pane (the bottom middle) in hardwood frame arranged to slide horizontally. Winter sashes to be provided with strong hooks and eyes.

Wooden Shutters:-
The windows of school-room are to have outside wooden shutters of narrow vertical sheeting and to be hung
Wooden Shutters:— hung in two leaves over the window sashes. Provide and fix all necessary window lifts and window and shutter fasteners.

Carry simple architraves at least 5" wide around windows and doors.

Floors:—

All floors, except shed floor, are to be double, the lower one being of roughboards laid close and well nailed. The upper floor is to be laid with 7/8" tongued and grooved hardwood or selected pine flooring in narrow widths and blind nailed. Put a layer of heavy sheeting paper between the two floors. The finished floor is not to be laid until after the plastering is done.

Floor the part of the shed where marked on the plan with 2" plank, floor to be carried on 3" x10" joists laid at 16" centres.

The veranda floor and steps to be floored with 1 1/8" yellow pine tongued and grooved, 3" flooring in narrow widths, laid with paint between joints.

The floor of the belfry is to be covered with galvanized iron.

Platform:—

A platform is to be made on the floor of the school-room where shown on plan. Joists 2 X 6 inches at 16" centres, and floored same as school floor. Put on facing board and nosing complete.

Closet and Book Shelves:—

Build in a simple cloak closet, with one shelf, 7' high, and a book shelf with four shelves as shown on the plan. Height of book shelf to be 4' from the platform.

Closet to have lock and key.

Lath and Plastering:—

Lath and plaster the whole of the walls and ceiling of the school and cloak rooms, not otherwise specified.
Lath and Plastering: specified. Plaster with two coats and hard finish.

The first two coats to be carried behind the wainscoting, architraves, etc.

Blackboard: Provide and put in place above the wainscoting, at the back of the platform a framed blackboard 3 1/3 feet by 10 feet of "Compo Slate Blackboard" or other approved material.

Belfry: Build a simple belfry as drawn on the drawing. The ceiling under the belfry is to have 2 X 2 ft. trap door with a suitable register framed into it. Lay on walk of 2" plank, 2' wide and 6' long from both sides of this trap door across the ceiling joists.

Provide and place a bell to cost complete $5. The rope from the bell is to be carried on pulleys over the ceiling and to enter the clock room in the chimney recess near the entrance from the porch.

Clothes Hooks: Provide and fix three dozen clothes hooks on the walls of the cloak room. Hooks to be in two rows of 4 and 5 feet above the floor and staggered.

Painting: Knot, prime, stop and paint in two coat work the whole of the wood-work, not otherwise specified. The outside wood work to be painted with white lead and linseed oil in two skim colours, light brown with dark brown facings.

Glaze all lights with clear medium heavy glass.

Water Closets: The water closets, two in number, are to be built in accordance with the accompanying drawing.

Dig soil pits and timber (cedar) the same as shown.

The undersigned begs to state that a resolution has been passed by the Nipissing Band of Indians in favour of the expenditure of a sufficient amount from their capital to erect a schoolhouse at the Garden Indian village on their reserve, on Lake Nipissing, in the district of Nipissing and province of Ontario. Extract from report of Inspector J. M. Bennett on the Garden Village School dated February 6, 1920. Original on 280075/6.

1. The school building needs a coat of paint in the worst way to preserve the wood from the weather.

2. The floor is full of "ruts" and needs attention. A new floor is necessary.

3. Seats are an urgent matter.

X X X

1. Every other desk is broken and seats are in such condition that any person would condemn them. Thirty five single desks should be furnished as soon as possible.

2. There is no pump and no source of drinking water except the lake. It is a question whether such water is safe.
Ottawa, February 24, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, in a report to the Department on his recent inspection of the Garden Village Indian Day School, states that the school building at this point needs a coat of paint in the worst way and that the floor is full of ruts and needs attention. He states that a new floor is necessary.

The Inspector also states that every other desk is broken and the seats are in such a condition that any person would condemn them. He states that thirty-five single desks should be furnished as soon as possible.

He also states that there is no pump and no source of drinking water, except the lake, and it is a question whether such water is safe.

I have to request that you will be good enough to furnish an estimate of the cost of painting the school building and laying a new floor. If funds can be provided, this work might be carried out during the next summer holidays.

With reference to the desks I have to request that you will furnish a list of the sizes required and the number of each size, or, if it is not possible to do this, you should give the ages of the children and the number of each age. Kindly give this information regarding the desks as soon as possible.

You should also look into the question of providing a pump for the use of the school and state whether, in your opinion, it would be possible to obtain water within a reasonable depth and the probable cost of boring a well.

Kindly give all the above matters your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Geo. F. Cockburn, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sturgeon Falls, Ont.

Memorandum:

Honourable Mr. Meighen,

Early in the year Mr. J.M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, visited the Garden Village Indian day school, which is located in the Nipissing reserve, Ont., for the purpose of making an inspection, and in his report he states that the school is badly in need of being painted, and a new floor should be laid.

We instructed the Indian Agent to obtain prices from different firms and submit them to the Department. He has done so, and the lowest tender is $875.00.

This appears to be a fair and reasonable price for the work contemplated, and as it is desirable that the school should be painted and the repairs made during the summer holidays, I would recommend that the order be given. Payment would be made from the interest funds of the band, and I would ask your approval of the expenditure.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa. April 19, 1921.

Sir,-

The teacher of the Garden Village Indian Day School, in her annual report for the fiscal year ending March 31st, last, states as follows:- The walls and ceiling of the school building are very dirty and the windows need repairs. She also states that the fence is out of repair and that the teachers residence is in bad need of repair. She requests that a door be made to allow entrance from the sitting room to the school and this would prove a blessing in winter.

I have to request that you will furnish a report as to the repairs that are needed to both school and teacher's residence and furnish an estimate of the cost of having the school room walls and ceiling cleaned, windows repaired, the repairs necessary to the teacher's residence made, the door suggested by the teacher put in and the fence repaired. You should furnish this information at your early convenience in order that if it is decided to have any work done, it can be performed during the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLean,

OTTAWA, December 12th, 1921.

Sir,

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Garden Village Indian Day School, states that in order to secure water in the winter the pupils have to go out on the lake for over a mile and that, at times, this is very dangerous. He recommends that a well be dug in order that a supply of water can be obtained near the school.

I will be pleased if you will furnish a report regarding this matter, stating whether you would advise that a well be dug at this school, and, if so, the approximate cost involved in having the work done.

I will be pleased to have a report from you regarding this matter at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Geo. P. Cockburn, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sturgeon Falls, Ont.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No - 43-3-5 of the 12th instant with reference to The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Garden Village Indian Day School, states that in order to secure water in the winter the pupils have to go out on the lake for over a mile.

In connection I beg to report that owing to the situation it is doubtful whether a well can be secured at this place at a reasonable cost owing to a bed of flat rock which appears about four feet from the surface and which was contended with when excavating the cellar for the teacher's residence, some of the Indians have tried digging wells but without success, in some cases it was owing to swamp water. I would recommend that a test for a well be made early next spring after the frost disappears, this can be done at a small expense, and if a place can be located free from rock the cost of well would not be expensive, the approximate cost involved would be about $50.00.

Your Obedient Servant

Sir,

Sir,

I beg to report that the Garden Village School building was discovered on fire at 1 A.M. this morning and the fire extinguished by an Indian who resides adjacent to the school. From examination I am under the opinion that the fire started at the base of the air ventilation upon the floor of the class room from soot and sparks blowing down same from heavy winds. A portion of the floor and petition had to be chopped out in order to extinguish the fire. It will not be necessary to close the school to make the necessary repairs which will not be expensive.

I will have the air ventilator closed up with cement immediately and the repairs done to the building by one of the Indians who is competent. It may be necessary when this is done to have the present chimney built higher but this may not be necessary unless it smokes in the class room.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, informing the Department of the fire that occurred at the Garden Village Indian Day School building, the cause thereof and the damage done.

While at Sturgeon Falls Agency recently, I visited the Garden Village Day School.

I found the school building and teacher's residence to be very much in need of paint. It is too late, however, for this work to be done this fall but provision should be made for having it done in the spring. Indian labor can be used. The shingles on the school roof are in bad condition especially on the north side.

New pipes were urgently needed for the school stove and I instructed the agent to attend to that immediately.

The teacher's residence is very much in need of a heating stove. All that the teacher has at present is a small cook stove with a very small fire box and drafts which cannot be closed tightly. The result is that it is impossible to keep a fire in for even an hour at a time without putting in more fuel. If a small Quebec heater were supplied it could be set beside the cook stove and the same flue used by joining the pipes with a T joint. I consider this very necessary and would be pleased if you could authorize the agent to have one purchased.

The floor of the teacher's residence requires painting and if the paint is supplied I think the teacher will do the work.

There are a number of boys at this school who would like very much to have a football and I promised to mention it to the Department.

Ottawa, September 27, 1924.

Mr. Inspector Parker, who recently visited the Sturgeon Falls Agency, has brought to the attention of the Department certain requirements at the Garden Village Indian Day School. New pipes are urgently needed for the stove in the classroom. The teacher's residence is very much in need of a heating stove and the floor of the teacher's residence requires painting.

You may arrange for the purchase and installation of the new pipes required for the school. You may also purchase a small Quebec heater for the teacher's residence. Mr. Parker states that this heater could be placed beside the cook stove and the same flue used by joining the pipes with "T" joint. You may also purchase the paint required to paint the floor of the teacher's residence. We understand that if this paint is supplied, the teacher will perform the work of painting the floor. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the above purchase.

Mr. Parker further states that he found the school building and teacher's residence to be very much in need of paint. As it is too late this fall to have this work done, you should draw the matter to the attention of the Department early next spring, at the same time stating definitely the amount of painting that should be done and the approximate cost of the material and labour required.

The shingles on the school roof, especially on the north side, are in a bad condition. If it is necessary that they be repaired this fall, you may arrange to have any work required carried out in order to prevent the roof from leaking. If the roof requires to be re-shingled, it might be best to leave this until next spring, when any shingling and the painting of the buildings will receive attention.

Please attend to the purchase of the pipes for the school stove and the heating stove and paint for the floor of the teacher's residence.

We are ordering a football and when received will be sent to the teacher. This is to be for the use of the boys of the school.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th instant, regarding the repairs and painting required to the school and teacher's residence at the Garden Village Indian Day School, and stating the approximate cost of the material and labour in having the work done.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the reshingling of the roof of the school building and the painting of this and the teacher's residence, the work to be done by day labour under your supervision. You should arrange for the purchase of the material required, such as shingles, nails, paint and paper. It will be necessary to obtain competitive prices, and the purchase should be made by you from the firms quoting the lowest price. Time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed. These sheets should be signed in duplicate by the men to whom any money is paid for labour. If necessary, you may employ a competent foreman and engage Indians for the balance of the labour. The Department will forward you an advance, upon application, to pay the labourers, and blank sheets are enclosed for keeping the proper labour returns. It is noted that you estimate the actual cost of the material and labour will be approximately $340, and this amount should, if possible, not be exceeded. The funds for the purpose will be taken from the interest account at the credit of the Band.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of the materials. A memo. should accompany these vouchers showing the names of the firms asked by you to quote and the prices quoted.

You should make the necessary arrangements for the purchase of the material and for the labour at an early date and have the work commenced early in July, next. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to see that a satisfactory job is completed and at the lowest possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 24, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, regarding the request of the teacher of the Garden Village Indian Day School for a grant of $10 to purchase presents for a Christmas tree for the pupils.

In reply I have to say that, as our funds this year are extremely limited, all that can be allowed for the purpose is an amount not exceeding the sum of $6.00—the same as was provided last year. After the purchase has been made, you should obtain an itemized account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the articles. This, you should attach to a proper voucher form, in the usual manner, certify and forward to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

The Garden Village Day School, Nipissing reserve, is badly in need of painting and repairs to the wood work of the front porch and also the foundation. The front fence is down and beyond repair. The teacher's residence also needs painting. The property is in poor condition altogether. It is about 9 years since anything was done to the buildings. If funds are available this work ought to be done.

The teacher requested to be supplied with separate drinking cups and tooth brushes for each pupil. As a health measure this would be worth while.

(sgd) Thos. McGookin,

A.S. Williams, Esq.,

OTTAWA.
Ottawa, July 20, 1934.

Sir:

In a report regarding his recent visit to the Garden Village Indian Day School, Inspector McGookin states as follows:

"Repairs are required to the woodwork of the front porch and also the foundation."

Please let me know what expenditure will be necessary to make the repairs mentioned by the Inspector.

He states, further, that the school and teacher's residence require painting. Owing to lack of funds, it is not possible to consider painting the exterior of the school, but, if a small expenditure would do the work necessary in the interior of both buildings, you might let me know what amount you consider would be required.

The teacher requested separate drinking cups and toothbrushes. You may arrange for the purchase of the number of granite or enamel cups which you believe are needed. A supply of toothbrushes will be sent to the teacher from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The Garden Village Day School and Teacher's Residence are badly in need of painting. The porch of the residence is breaking away. It needs to be jacked into placed and securely fastened to the building.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF JUNE

Miss Morris, Teacher at Garden Village, closed her school on June 26th with a picnic for her pupils. Miss Morris has had a very good attendance all year and prizes were awarded.

I have inspected the Garden Village school and find it very badly in need of repairs. The roof would have to be shingled and the school and dwelling needs painting.

Voucher No.: 102

Date: July 9th, 1943

Indian Agent
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I am attaching herewith voucher No. 101, for paint required to finish Garden Village, Nipissing Reserve Indian Day School, teacher's house and garage.

You will recall that enough paint was bought last year for one coat but it was impossible to secure labour during the summer months of 1943.

This year the buildings had to be wire brushed and the paint purchased last year was only sufficient for a priming coat, consequently, it was necessary to purchase more paint for a second coat. It is a fair job but will need another coat next year in order to last. All openings on teacher's residence, windows, screens and storm windows for both school and house should also be painted but the men have all gone guiding for the summer.

The two outdoor toilets will need some minor repairs and be painted at first opportunity. They would also need to be emptied or removed farther.

All buildings, that is the school house, teacher's residence, garage and outhouses are covered with red asphalt shingles, which, in this vicinity, reduces the cost of fire insurance by 5%.

J. A. Marleau,
Indian Agent.

INDIAN AFFAIRS:

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs reporting the necessity for the construction of a small building for use as a residence for the teacher of the Garden Village Indian day school on the Nipissing Indian reserve, in the Strangefalls Agency, in the province of Ontario; that the cost of a suitable building containing two rooms on the ground floor and two rooms upstairs is estimated by the architect of the Department of Indian Affairs at $800.00.

The Superintendent General therefore recommends that under the provisions of Section 69 of the Indian Act authority be given for the expenditure of the above mentioned sum of $800.00 from the capital at the credit of the Nipissing band, which amounts to $117,246.93, on the construction of the building above referred to.

The Board concur in the above recommendation and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable
The Supt.-Gen. of Indian Affairs.

Department of Indian Affairs,

PLAN NO. 426

Specification of material and labour required in the erection and completion of a Teacher's Residence, Garden Village Reserve, Ont.

GENERAL CONDITIONS

The contractors to give their personal supervision to the work, to furnish all necessary materials, labour, apparatus, scaffolding and utensils useful for performing the work in the best and most satisfactory manner, according to the drawings and these particulars prepared for the same, and are intended to include everything necessary and requisite for the full and entire completion of the building, without exception, notwithstanding that every item necessarily involved in the work is not particularly mentioned, and work shown and not specified and vice versa, to be done as if both shown and specified.

All of the material to be of the best of the sorts and qualities specified and all to be sound and firm.

At completion the works to be given up in a complete and undamaged state without exception.

All the work to be finished in a plain and substantial way as specified and directed and to be to the entire satisfaction of an officer of the Department of Indian Affairs appointed for this purpose.
CARPENTRY AND JOINING

POSTS

Provide and sink in earth to the depth shown on Section drawing, moderately dry sound cedar posts cut from live cedar 10" at smallest end and resting on large flat stones at bottom.

Each post to have brace cut into and strongly spike-nailed to post as shown for sheeting.

SILLS

The sills for frame will be of 6" x 10"

built up of three pieces of 2" x 8" in long lengths and well spike-nailed together with 4" nails.

The sills will be evenly and firmly bedded level on cedar posts as shown and firmly secured together at corners.

JOISTS

The joists for ground floor will be of 2" x 10"

and ceiling 2" x 6" and set at 16" centres, bridged each six feet in length with 2" x 2" herring-boned bridging well nailed at each end with 2½" wire nails.

The joisting to be firmly nailed to sills or plates at each end with 4" spike-nails.

FRAMEWORK

Build framework of 2" x 4" scantling set at 16" centres, and having plate of 2" x 4" doubled in long lengths and well spike-nailed together at all angles. The foot of studding to rest on sill and to be strongly spike-nailed to sills and sides of joists with 4" nails.
ROOF

The rafters will be of 2" x 6" set at 24" centres, framed at heel and well and strongly spike-nailed to plates and together with 4" spike-nails. Rafters to have ridge board full length of ridge between points of rafters.

Provide and fix ceiling joists of 2" x 6" nailed to all plates and set at 16" centres.

ROUGH BOARDING

Cover all the outside frame and roof with good quality of narrow 7/8" spruce or fir shiplap boarding well nailed, close jointed with at least two 3" nails to each board, at each crossing of studding or rafter, the interior walls will be sheeted up with good quality of similar material as building paper before plastering.

SIDING

The exterior wall will be covered with two thicknesses of building paper on shiplap and finished with a good quality of narrow, dry weather-board siding. The siding will be neatly fitted and well and strongly nailed to boarding with 2½" finishing nails.

Provide and fix at all angles 7/8" x 4" corner strip to which siding will finish and to be strongly nailed to frame work as required.

WATER TABLE

Fix in position water table formed of 2" x 6" bevelled as required and shown, water table to be strongly spike-nailed to framework. The tongued and grooved sheeting under water table to be firmly nailed to sill and ribbon piece in post. A rough board to be placed outside of sheeting to which earth will be graded.
SHINGLES

The roof to be covered with best quality of British Columbia or other Canadian cedar shingles laid at 4½" to weather on double thicknesses of asbestos or tarred roofing felt and nailed with best quality 1¾" steel shingle nails of Canadian manufacture. To have, at least, two nails to each 4" shingle.

PARTITIONS

The interior partitions will be of 7/8" x 3" tongued and grooved sheeting, dressed both sides and reinforced with rail 3 ft. above floor and strongly nailed at floor-line and at ceiling.

FLOORING

Cover the ground floor joists with good quality of rough, narrow spruce, fir or cedar lumber laid diagonally, with close joints and well nailed to joisting with 3" nails. Cover this sub-floor with two thicknesses of oiled building or tarred roofing paper then lay good quality of narrow tongued and grooved flooring blind nailed with 2¼" finishing nails at each crossing of joist.

SHEETING

Cover all walls, partitions and ceiling with good quality of narrow tongued and grooved V jointed pine, fir or cedar sheeting on building paper, well lapped and strongly blind-nailed at each crossing of joisting with 2¼" finishing nails.
TRIM

All doors and windows to be trimmed with a neat 5" architrave and all rooms unless otherwise specified to have 10" base, all to be hand-smoothed and put on in a good and workmanlike manner.

WINDOW FRAMES

Provide and fix 7/8" pine box window frames size shown, having all necessary hanging stiles, blind-stiles, outside and inside casings, stops, parking strips, sills, sub-sills, back band, etc., complete and to have 1½" double hung sash to all windows, all to have suitable lifts and fasts put on complete.

DOORS AND FRAMES

Provide and fix suitable front porch and rear outside door frames, formed of 2" pine rebated for 1½" door having blind stiles, with back band for storm doors.

The exterior doors will be of good quality 1½" pine balustrade moulded, as shown on elevation drawing. The porch and rear door to be similar as shown. All to be hung with 4" x 4" steel loose pin butt 1½" screws and locked with a good quality brass-faced and bolted door locks having all necessary roses, escutcheons, etc., complete, as required.

OUTSIDE STEPS

Build outside steps as shown to front and rear having 1½" strings, 1 3/8" treads and 7/8" risers of pine housed into strings.
The steps will be well and strongly put together having strong carriage pieces and to be well nailed, blocked and glued. All to be hand-smoothed and sand-papered.

PORCH

The porch to be built as shown having similar joists, sills, etc., as specified for building. The flooring to be laid plain 7/8" x 4" with joists 1/8" apart and strongly nailed to joists.

The porch posts to be 6 x 6 and to have a neat cornice finished as shown. A lattice to be fitted under the floor and strongly nailed together.

EXCAVATION

Excavate to the depth and size shown on plan for cellar, the earth being graded to the level required.

Plank up the walls with 3" planking to the joists carefully covering all crevices to keep out the air. The outside of walls before filling to be covered with waterproof felt and earth graded to top of walls.

Provide window frames as shown in covered passage to cellar with sash in outer wall, also in plank wall in cellar. The sash to be glazed similar to other windows.

CORNICE

The cornice of buildings, porch, etc., will be formed of 7/8" fascia and tongued and grooved soffit having all necessary crown and bed moulds and cove as required.

NOTE

The carpenter contractor to erect strong bracket shelf for chimney where shown and to do any furring, cutting in carpenter work where necessary for other trades. The building to be left clean and ready for occupation at completion.
PAINTING AND GLAZING

PAINTING

Paint the whole of the exposed portions of wood and iron usually painted, three good coats of lead and oil, tinted as directed.

The lead to be the best manufactured Canadian white lead, pure boiled linseed oil and turpentine as dryers. All to be neatly stopped and knotted, and sand-papered between coats.

COLOURS

The colours to be used are to be of good quality ground in oil.

GLAZING

Glaze the whole of the windows and doors, after priming with white lead and oil, with best quality of 16 oz. Pilkington English sheet glass. All glass to be sprigged and back and front putted.

PUTTY

The putty used throughout to be best white lead and linseed oil putty. All to be finished and given up in a good and workmanlike condition.
TIN AND GALVANIZED IRON

Provide and fix necessary cleft flashings over all window and door frames to prevent water getting behind frames. The flashings to be of at least 6" in width and to be fixed in position before siding is put on.

All galvanized iron to be Lysaght Queen's Head Brand, twenty-eight gauge galvanized iron.

BRICKLAYER

Provide on brackets a chimney 18" square, having a nine inch flue of best quality hard burned well clay bricks, laid in good mortar and pargetted throughout. The necessary cleaning out, and smoke flue rings are to be built in with stops for each hole.

The whole of the work to be done in a good and satisfactory manner.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And J. K. McConnell

of Sturgeon Falls, Ont. (hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the Teacher's residence at Garden Village Indian School, Plan No. 426.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the First day of December A. D. 1919.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of One thousand three hundred and twenty———dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any, due to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

I have received intimation from Mr Hoddge, the teacher of the Indian school at Georgina Island, of his wish to resign, and to be relieved of school duties early in March. In view of the charges preferred against me by some of the Indians, I would say that concerning the opening of the school that I wanted to start, my two boys were home and I had not been away myself scarcely all summer but I had been informed that the if less than five pupils went on the Reserve I was not supposed to teach. This is a fact. I did not consider that I was under any obligation to open the school with the number present. I went to camp meeting, Christian Island where I met several teachers at least three, one of which had not opened his school since the holidays for the same reason as myself for the want of pupils.

As to the farming operations I have none except moving hay on the lot or Mission grounds and some elsewhere in the holidays.

I have a number of small pigs that have not done any body any harm, the old ones were kept quite closely on the Mission grounds since the hay was cut previously they were well confined in a large run of pasture.

Please allow me to say that I have not lost School time over my stock we rise early and do our Chores and are not aiming to be an example.
of kindness to the Indians. I have not thrown away the valuable school hours, as any person may say. Nor have I neglected Divine service either in the Sunday School or Church, my wife assisting me in the Sunday School. If it is deemed an error she not having opened the school with the number of pupils present, only two of which might have come, I believe, and one of them went to the doctor yesterday for examination. Regretting very much and in future I intend to keep school open at the number of pupils be ever so small. Please advise me in case my duties as Teacher and as Missionary conflict which should I attend to first? On the greater part of the Indians on the Reserve are perfectly satisfied. I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 15217/1 dated Sep 12th 1907 and to report in regard to complaints made with reference to the teacher on Georgina Island. I heard very little complaints about the way the school was taught until the holidays. I was on the reserve all day on the 13th of August and heard some complaints about some small pigs and a breach owned by the teacher. Although I had got the matter settled, the teacher agreeing to sell or take care of the animals complained of. During the rest of August I seen the old chief and other Indians frequently and heard fresh complaints and supposed the school was reopened at the proper time, as the teacher told me he would do. Dear Sir,

The Indians had a pow wow Wednesday Feb 10th which became a failure. They tried it again Thursday Feb 18th but they were still behind. They have a social this evening. In the interval I kept school each day. Today—Friday—the Inspector visited our school. The place was in great disorder owing to nuts, candies, tobacco and other dirt on the school house floor. The candy stand was still standing in the school house. He asked a gentleman in button if the Pow wow would interfere with...
the Indian School he told he thought it would be done over and found us all in a mess. It had been understood the night before with the caretaker that he clean the school house on Friday consequently there would be no school. Whenupon the Inspector on the absence of children proposed to base his examination upon the Register so at it he went in a great fervor of criticism and I sat quite made up my mind that it would be impossible to please him so I declined.
any further examination except when I had no children. Re. Georgina Island School.

I was on the Island from the evening of the 9th to the morning of the 12th instant and arranged a truce between the teacher and the chief, the latter agreeing to Mr. Prosser's remaining until the first of April. This would give him an opportunity to secure another position and I suggested to him that he might try and arrange a transfer with Mr. Cork, who is at present teaching at Chemong. He would be well pleased if such an exchange could be arranged and I do not see that there should be any difficulty about it.

Mr. Cork, who is a superannuated Public School teacher, told me that his wife did not care to go to live at Chemong permanently, and as his family all live in Toronto he could easily get home from Sutton by the trolley car which makes the trip in less than three hours, whereas it is more than a day's journey from Chemong to his home.

Mr. Prosser is a personal friend of Chief Wetung, who is an easy man to get along with, while Chief Bekannew is the reverse. The difficulty between him and Mr. Prosser being that they are both local preachers and neither one wished to give way to the other. While Mr. Cork is a member of the Methodist Church he would raise no objection to Chief Bekannew holding services as frequently as he liked, which is his ambition and the chief cause of trouble between him and Mr. Prosser. I think if this exchange could be arranged it would be agreeable to all parties.

I met Mr. Milley, the Inspector who sent in the adverse
adverse report on Mr. Presser and from a conversation I had with him I concluded that it was more a question of offended dignity than a lack of teaching ability on Mr. Presser's part that led him to make the report he did. He admitted to me that Mr. Presser was competent to teach in an Indian school. While Mr. Prooser has his peculiarities he is a earnest, good man and well thought of in the community, and I am sure would do better at Shemong. It would be time enough to make an exchange after the holidays as it is impossible for him to leave the Island till the ice is formed, in fact I think the end of March would be the most suitable time for him to get off the Island.

On the following morning I again saw Mr. Yates and he told me that Mr. Prosser, teacher of the Georgina Island school, had been in town the day previous, and, after telephoning to his relatives and calling on the Methodist Missionary, I found him and, as he was anxious to get back to the Island, he volunteered to take me over. We walked down to Jackson's Point and, after a most exciting trip, arrived safely.
safely on the other side late that night. On Thursday morning I called on Chief Bigcanoe who had asked for the removal of Mr. Prosser from the school and made temporary arrangements about Mr. Prosser, both agreeing that he should give up the school by the 1st of April. This was satisfactory to both the Chief and the Teacher and was the best way out of the difficulty that I could see, as the Chief was insistent that Mr. Prosser should leave and was backed up by Dr. Sutherland and the Public School Inspector, and, in fact, Mr. Prosser had already sent in his resignation.

I inspected the school and found 5 Indian boys present, no girls. There was a heavy snow storm, the first of the season, which may have accounted for the small attendance although they knew I was on the Island for the purpose of visiting the school and a better showing might have been expected. The children were backward and considering that Mr. Prosser has had charge of the school for four years better results should have been apparent. He has experienced opposition from the Chief, who wishes to be at the head of affairs on the Island, both spiritual and temporal, and as Mr. Prosser was not willing to recognize the Chief as his head or take directions from him trouble began, and the only solution of the difficulty will be the removal or transfer of Mr. Prosser to some other field. While Mr. Prosser has his peculiarities he is an earnest, good man and well thought of in the community, and, although teaching school is not his strong point or his proper vocation, he has sufficient education to conduct an Indian school if surroundings were more congenial.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of Dec. 31, 1910, I may say that as the pupils of this school are such active players of games I thought a systematic calisthenic drill to be quite superfluous. In the summer the boys play base ball, wrestle and have racing contests. I also taught them to play leap-frog in which they never saw before. The girls play "it" or "tag" and other running games. In winter the boys play hockey or "shinny" on the ground, wrestle, "pull away" or "take out jack", while both boys and girls join in the game of "it" or "tag", blind man's buff, etc. The children never stay in the school house except during school hours. Dear Sir:

I should be very glad to cooperate with the Department in securing the services of Miss Lawrence when a suitable vacancy occurs.

Since that time, the Committee of our Church who are in touch with conditions at Georgina Island, have sent us a resolution strongly advocating securing a married man for this position, on the ground that a Christian home is very much needed as an influence both upon the school children, and throughout the community.

REPORT ON GEORGINA ISLAND RESERVE.

R.H. Abraham, B.S.A.

SCHOOL.

The teacher, Mr. Jones, is an Englishman who has never taught school before. He is, I think, qualified to take up all the lessons but he has no idea what to teach each class. He should be supplied with the Ont. Dept. of Education's school manuals for 1915, which takes up each subject and outlines the lessons that should be taught to each class. There is a separate manual for each subject, eleven in all and they can be bought for about $2.00 per set. I can secure them and mail them to him if so instructed. These manuals will be a great assistance to teachers who have not had normal training.

There are 22 pupils on the roll, 28 of school age on the Island. The average attendance is 16. They have no truant officer at present. One should be appointed at a salary of about $12.00 a year, to be paid when the attendance is 75% or better of the total number of children on school age and no pay when the attendance falls below this.

The closets should be moved as they are too close together. The girl's closet is good but the boy's is small poor, too small with no shile. A new one should be constructed.

AGRICULTURE IN THE SCHOOL.

For next year the Chief has promised to prepare a school garden and to organize a school fair. The Indian Agent should be notified to give him every encouragement in this.

Dear Sir:

Re Georgina Island:

Your letter is to hand enclosing a copy of a letter from Mr. A. Crozier, threatening action against the missionary for damages done by his dog.

By unexpected good fortune I was able to have an immediate interview with Rev. J. W. Arnott, of Sutton, who is Superintendent of this mission and has been closely in touch with the whole situation. As usual there are two sides to the story. In the main, however, the allegations against the missionary's dog are admitted. The charge of being abusive to the aged chief, or more correctly, the ex-chief Charles Big Canoe, is explained by the fact that the old gentleman and the missionary had a rather serious altercation in a public place. According to my information neither of them recall the argument with any special pride or pleasure.

Rev. Mr. Arnott has interviewed the missionary, the lawyer, the Indian Agent, Mr. Boucher, the ex-chief Charles Big Canoe, his son Albert, with whom the old gentleman makes his home, and other members of his family. He assures me that there is a disposition all round to settle the matter without legal procedure, and at least a possibility of restoring reasonably good relations between the missionary and the Big Canoe family.

In view of the obvious advantage of such a course, I beg to recommend that the matter be placed for settlement in the hands of Rev. J. W. Arnott and the Indian Agent, Mr. Boucher, and that all parties be advised to accept their settlement. Mr. Arnott has expressed his willingness to undertake this work in cooperation with Mr. Boucher if it is the wish of the Indian Department.

In the meantime, I shall very strongly urge upon

MEMORANDUM:

Acting Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Rev. A. Lloyd Smith, Assistant Secretary, Board of Home Missions of the Methodist Church, requests that an increase in salary be granted to Miss Grace Martin, teacher of the Georgina Island Indian Day School, which school is conducted under the auspices of the above named church. After an interview with Miss Martin he states that she will not go back to this school another year unless she receives an increase in salary.

Miss Martin is an Indian, 27 years of age. She has had three years' experience as teacher in Indian schools, two of which were on the Six Nations' Reserve, and last year at Georgina Island. She has no professional qualifications, having had only a high school training. Salary allowed is at the rate of $600 per annum, together with bonus at the rate of $150. She also receives $50.00 for mission work from the Methodist Church. Favourable reports have been received regarding her work, and that she is making a success at this school.

Rev. Mr. Smith points out that the teachers at Parry Island, where the circumstances are similar, are receiving a considerably larger salary than Miss Martin. Miss Huffman who taught the Ryerson School was paid $800 per annum and bonus of $150. She has had normal training and a 3rd class certificate. Mrs. English, who taught the Shawanaga, received a salary of $750 per annum and bonus at the rate of $150. She also had a 3rd class professional certificate, with model training.

Owing to the isolation of Georgina Island it is difficult to obtain a good teacher, and as Miss Martin has done good work it would be advisable to retain her services, and I would recommend that she be granted an increase of $100 from the beginning of the new school year. The Band Funds contribute $250 towards the salary and the balance is paid from the general vote for Indian education.

"The preacher-teacher combination fairly works well. Mr. Ward may preach acceptably to adults (I don't know) but he is a poor teacher for children. He talks and talks and most of the time goes over the heads of the pupils. He wastes time in wordy explanations that are lost on the pupils.

For some years no pupil has reached the H.S. Entrance although several could have done so under proper guidance and teaching. Pupils with few exceptions have good ability, attend pretty regularly until about 16 years of age. Now that a thousand teachers are without schools, it should be easily possible to obtain a qualified teacher. No change can however be made immediately or possibly before next June.

As a free house is provided a married teacher or one with a relative for companion and housekeeper might be secured. Many male teachers are without schools.

Teacher does not get best work from his pupils. Reading is expressionless. Answers to questions asked, poor, never in correct form. Teacher does not teach how answers should be given, accepts wrong and poor answers.

Arithmetic seems to be in better condition. Grammar poorly taught. Conclusion: some progress is being made, but more, much more could be possible.

I believe Mr. Ward has as a man and a preacher been fairly acceptable to the people but he is not a clear or effective teacher for children. I shall try and assist him while he remains."

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant enclosing the June quarter return of the Georgina Island Day School, as well as a voucher for the teacher's salary for that period.

In reply I beg to inform you that cheques to the amount of $125.00, being the amount of salary due Mr. Cork, the teacher, are being sent you. This is payment in full for his services at this school to June 30th, last.

The school year begins after the summer holidays, September 1st, and ends June 30th, during which period the Department requires that the school be taught 200 days. Mr. Cork began duties at the Mud Lake School in September, 1909, and was transferred to Georgina Island April 1st, 1910, where he has taught continuously up to June 30th, last, a period of six years, which he has been in the employ of the Department and for which he has received six years' salary. There is, therefore, no further amount due him for his services.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Dear Sir:

Mr. Bouchier, the Indian Agent at Sutton has sent me a copy of your letter to him re my claim for salary for a portion of the holidays. Now, I respectfully submit that your statement of the case is not in accordance with the paragraphs in your "regulations" referring to the payment of teachers for "broken time". I have not a copy of the regulations at hand as it is hanging in the school house. The Ont. Public School law contains the same regulations as to teachers' salaries for "broken time". According to your statement of the case if I were to commence teaching on Sept 1st at a salary of $500 per annum, and quit on June 30th the following year, I would only be entitled to $496.66 while I have taught the whole
School year. I have taught six full school years but have received payment for only five years' holidays; why not for the sixth? According to your view of the matter no one will be paid for the holidays and the Dept. will be that much ahead because of a change of teachers. I am sure that if you will reconsider the matter you cannot but come to the conclusion that I am right and that my claim is a just one.

If you will allow me to withdraw my resignation till the end of the year, why that would put everything right. When I resigned I supposed that my claim would be allowed without any doubt.

Yours respectfully,

Geo. Cook.
Ottawa, August 13, 1915.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant in reference to your claim for salary for a portion of the holidays as teacher of the Georgina Island School and stating that if the Department would allow you to withdraw your resignation till the end of the year that would put everything right.

FORM 14
Ottawa, February 16th, 1927.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 16th instant, reporting an outbreak of measles on the Georgina Island Reserve. It is noted that, owing to the small attendance of pupils, you have instructed the teacher to close the school. In reply I beg to say that the action taken under the circumstances is approved. It is hoped that this disease will soon abate and that there will be no fatalities among the children of school age. You should arrange to have the school re-opened as soon as you consider it advisable to do so.

The teacher, in preparing his quarterly return for the current quarter, should state clearly therein the dates between which the school was closed on account of the outbreak of measles. You will be good enough to advise him accordingly.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Georgina Island Indian Day School, No. 392.

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Mr. W. Stewart Miner, effective at the end of this month. No further salary should be paid to him after that date.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Georgina Island Indian Day School, No. 392.

In my memorandum of January 15 I advised you of the resignation of Mr. W. Stewart Miner, effective January 31, 1948.

To succeed him the Department has appointed Mr. Lorenzo Big Canoe. He will begin duties on March 9 and will be in charge of the school to the end of June, 1948. His salary will be at the rate of $85.00 a teaching month plus bonus. The staff questionnaire, cost-of-living bonus form and National Defence Tax form will be forwarded in the near future. I enclose copy of letter of appointment.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, December 19, 1947.

Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

Re: Georgina Island Indian Day School No. 392

Mr. Frank J. Joblin, Sutton West, Ontario, gave up duties at the above school on June 30th, 1947 after completing a period of twenty six years as teacher in different Indian day schools.

Under such circumstances in the past it has been the practice to allow two months salary upon retirement. Consequently, Mr. Joblin should be forwarded a cheque for $224.00 representing two months salary at the rate he was being paid during the last academic year.

Sir,

I beg to report that the school at Georgina Island needs some repairs. The windows and doors need repair, one new seat, but repaired, the walls and ceiling whitening, the closet improving, the black board painting. The above repairs would make the building comfortable for the winter if banked up at the foundation. The building is frame placed on said cedar posts and will require a stone wall under it in a year or two. The expenses of the bank will be heavy this summer and they would like to defer the stone wall for the present.

The repairs I propose to do now will cost about twenty dollars.

I have the honor to remain your obedient servant,

John Gale,

Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 152197 dated 6th July 1903 asking for estimates of costs of repairs to Indian School house on Georgina Island, the cost will be as follows:

- Raising Building: £10.00
- Constructing stone foundation 22 inches thick: £50.00
- 4 feet high furnishing all material: £30.00
- Painting outside side of building: £5.00
- Screen for 2 closets: £3.00
- Pathway from road to school house: £3.00

Total: £98.00

We are putting up a wire fence at a cost of about £25.00, as the school house is old. I don't think it would be advisable to go to the expense of a stone foundation as before many years there will have to be a new one built. The outside of the building could be kept clean with some cheap paint. This is the case the Indians approve of and I fully agree with them.

The Secretary of
The Dept. of Indian Affairs Ottawa

Your obedient servant,

Vachell December 17th 1903

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 1521477-5A dated 10th June 1903, with reference to the resolution regarding the painting the school house on Georgia Island. I beg to explain that the reason I did not send it to the Dept when passed was that I thought your letter No. 1521477-5A dated 15th July 1903 authorized the expenditure. The estimate I sent in was for outside painting and to be done with white lead, and the resolution asked for some kind of cheap paint which I could not find till quite late in the fall so we had to wait till spring to paint the schoolhouse. Chief By canoe got cheap paint on his house just before winter set in, if it stands the weather well this winter we want to paint the schoolhouse and council hall in the spring outside with the same kind of paint. I will send estimates and resolutions of the Board before doing the work.

Your obedient servant,
John Eaton
Indian Agent
