Dear Sir,

In compliance with your request of July 24th, No. 52137, I yesterday paid a visit to Georgina Island Indian School. I did not send word in advance, as on my first visit, as I wished to know the usual condition of the school. But unfortunately, I found on arriving that the school had been closed for two or three days on account of a Church Tea-meeting.

The teacher—Mr. Crosser—came with me to the school, but was extremely independent in his manner. I found names of nine pupils entered in his register. On my asking for their ages and classes, and the average attendance (none of which information could be found from the register) he became angry and grew insolent, and in effect told me to mind my own business as he knew how to manage the school better than I could tell him, &c., &c. In fact, it was impossible to talk to him or get any information from him as to the school.
I understand the Department sent an inspector some time ago, to inspect the school and as a result of this inspection and report Mr. Crosser resents any visit from me.

I appreciate the difficulty of obtaining a suitable person for this position, and know that great allowance must be made for lack of scholarship and teaching ability; but the great lack in this case is of common sense. Mr. P. is a poor, weak-minded man—quite unfit for the position. I find that only a few are sending their children, the average being perhaps 3 or 4 pupils. In justice to the Indians I recommend the Department to secure a more sensible man for this position.

If it were possible to combine the positions of Indian Agent, and Teacher, a better salary could be given and a better man secured.

Yours Truly,

C.W. Mulloy
Department of Indian Affairs.

Sir,

I have to ask you to be good enough to let the Department have a full and comprehensive report with reference to the condition of the school on Georgina Island. It would appear to be necessary either to erect a new building or to make some extensive repairs to the present one. If you consider the building can be repaired you should report definitely what repairs are needed and give an approximate estimate of the cost. This should receive your early attention in order that a decision may be arrived at within a short time and the work performed during the approaching summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Sutton West, Ont.
Sir,

In compliance with your letter No. 21775 of May 15th, 1911, asking for a report with reference to the condition of the school house on Georgina Island, I beg to report as follows:

I went and made a careful inspection. The building is 24 ft. wide and 28 ft. long, quite large enough for the number of pupils that are likely to attend school on the reserve. The roof is very leaky and has caused quite a lot of the plaster to fall off the ceiling; the outside of the building is in very good condition, but needs painting; the walls which rest on posts is quite sound; the building is near the ground it would require raising one foot and a cement foundation; the lobby or entrance is too small, it would need a new one, the laths and plaster on the ceiling would have to be taken off and replastered or a metallic ceiling put on. To put the school house in a comfortable and sanitary condition, it would need shingling and ceiling and painting and a foundation and a new lobby. If these repairs were made the school building would answer quite as well as a new one for many years to come. I enclose Estimates.

Your obedient servant,

John Gates
Agent.

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir:

While at Georgian Is. recently I visited the school and found it in a very bad shape. A foundation was put under the school and this foundation was provided for brick veneer over the school. The outside of the school is in a very dilapidated condition and the wind can blow right through into the building. You can see daylight from the inside in a number of places and there is not storm windows of any kind on the windows. This is a very cold district and I consider it is absolutely essential for the health of the children that the school should be repaired. It is 25 x 35 with 11' walls. It would not require a very large expenditure to put the school in shape. It should be papered first with a heavy paper over the outside of the siding and then veneered.

I also learned that there is no wood provided for the coming winter at the school. The Agent stated that the Indians would not work unless he had the money already to pay them. I think it would be very important indeed to have a supply of wood cut and piled in the shed as soon as possible. It would cost approximately $2.00 per cord to have this wood cut and hauled to the wood shed. It will require about 25 cords. I would recommend that an accountable cheque for $50 be forwarded to the Indian Agent and he be instructed to have the wood cut immediately.

The laboratories are also in very poor condition there being no door whatever on the girls and no shield. The boys laboratory is also out of repair. The teacher of the school, Mr. Jones, asked me if there was no way we could have the library of the school traded with some other school. He states that the children have read all the books and it is, therefore, of no use any more.

Yours truly,

J. D. McLean, Secy.,

In reply I beg to say that the arrangement which you recommend for having the above work done is approved. You may therefore engage the services of a competent man who understands the work, and hire Indian labour in carrying it out. The outside walls of the building should be covered with a heavy building paper and then veneered, or cemented. You will purchase and have delivered all material needed. If possible, secure competitive prices, and obtain the goods from the firm quoting the lowest price.

It will be necessary for you to personally oversee the work and keep proper time sheets of the labour employed. These should be signed, in the column for that purpose, by the men when payment is made them. A supply of the forms is enclosed herewith.

If you require an advance to pay wages, you should requisition for the amount you consider necessary. The Department will leave the matter of these repairs in your hands, but you will please incur no unnecessary expenditure. Please attend to the matter at once, in order that the work can be finished before the extreme cold weather sets in.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. J. Kay, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sutton West, Ont.

Extract from report of Inspector Mulloy on the Georgina Island Indian Day School, dated Oct. 2, 1925.

Original on file 10-1-6.

"........ Some time ago the school building was lathed and plastered on outside but a poor job was made as plaster is falling off.

"Interior has been lined, ceiling and walls, with sheet metal and a pretty good job made. It should now be painted, ceiling light cream and walls light fawn and wainscoting etc., light oak. This will make a pleasant room where the children will like to be.

The closets are in pretty good condition, well separated and screened. Painting is needed and hat & cap hooks for clothing, etc.,"
Ottawa, December 14th, 1925.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a recent report on his inspection of the Georgina Island Indian Day School, states that some time ago the school building was lathed and plastered on the outside, but that a poor job was made, as the plaster is falling off. He recommends that the interior of the school building be painted, the ceiling light cream and the walls light fawn and the wainscoting light oak. He states that if this is done it will make the classroom bright and pleasant for the pupils. He further states that the closets require painting, and that hooks for clothing are required in the school.

I shall be pleased to have a report from you concerning the Inspector's recommendation. You should state the cost of repairing the plaster on the outside of the building, the painting of the interior, as suggested by the Inspector, and also the painting of the toilets. Please state whether you could arrange to have the painting of the interior of the schoolroom carried out during the coming Christmas holidays, and if you would advise that the work be done at that time.

You may arrange to have the number of hooks required for the clothing installed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. J. Kay, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sutton West, Ont.
Sir,

Re Your Letter No. 1015 dated Dec 14th. As Report of School Inspector. The school was repaired on the outside a couple of years ago and sorry to say was not satisfactory. I watched the same kind of jobs being done here in town which certainly look well and as solid as need be. Rather hard sometimes to get men to go to the Island to do much work only country this time going & coming and you have to be on the job all the time to get results. The latter job I got and old Mason who had worked on the job some forty years to do the work. Then in order to help the Indians get them to do all the rough work carrying, whipping etc. The old Mason complained afterwards he could not get the Indians to mix according to his instructions but he never mentioned it to me when the work was being done. Some of it is dropping off. Also it has not had the best of care they tell me the School Teacher who I know is not too particular allows the boys to throw...
Sir,

balls etc against the school which started some of it to crack. Also I do know I went there one day and to my surprise they had piled the seasons wood against the back end of school. Certainly this left its marks to date. I do not just know how to repair will find out next spring. As for painting I was talking to the Inspector in the School while he was there colors etc. would not advise painting this Xmas holidays unless we got extra good weather. However I will see a painter and if he recommends the job may change my mind. Re the Closets they are built of rough lumber painting would improve their appearance and possibly a coat of stain would answer the purpose just as well. However they are 90% better shape now than they have been for years.

I certainly would like to see these buildings kept in good repair and will do my best any authority you may give me. I have always favored the Indian trying to give him the work.
Sir,

If possible but the best of them only make good helps should have some one to go ahead with the work. The interior certainly needs painting and I was glad we got the walls all done over with metal siding before the inspectors visit. Also the new seats that I got and put in helps the whole surroundings look much better than they did a couple of years ago only room for a few improvements yet if funds will allow.

Your obedient servant

W.J. Kay

Adjut.
Ottawa, December 18th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, relative to the repairs and painting required to the Georgina Island Indian Day School building.

In reply I beg to say that owing to weather conditions it is considered that it would be advisable to allow the repairs and painting to the school building and closets to remain over until early next spring. You should bear this matter in mind and forward a request in due time for the necessary authority to have the work undertaken. At that time you should state definitely the work you would recommend be done, the approximate cost of same, and how you would advise that the work be performed. It would, no doubt, be advisable to place the work under the charge of a competent white foreman, employing Indian labour as far as possible, you to arrange for the purchase and supplying of all materials required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. J. Kay, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sutton West, Ont.

Original on File 10-1-6.

As I have suggested, the classroom should be swept daily. The stove pipes smoke. The pipes should be taken down and cleaned and also the opening into the chimney to see whether this can be prevented. School cannot be kept open in cold weather under these conditions.

The girls' closet seat has only one small hole in it. The large girls are bound to either wet the front of it or dirty the back part. The seat is dirty now and the closet is dirty. These conditions should be changed before cold weather sets in. I have had a talk with the agent and he is going over to see what can be done.

The rough-cast has fallen off the outside of the school building in many places. This also should be looked after.

There is nothing in the classroom that can be locked to hold registers or other supplies. The teacher has to carry these home and back to school. This should be remedied at once.

Carried.

Resolution No. 5.

O. J. Silver.
Indian Agent.
GEORGINA ISLD. MINUTES OF COUNCIL MEETING HELD DEC.27, 1935.
& Jan. 29, 1936.

No. 3.

Tom BigCanoe, J.R.Ashquabe moved in view of
the dangerous condition of the school house stove it is
strongly recommended that a new stove and pipes be purchased,
also a new floor laid. The Indian Agent is hereby instructed
to notify the Board of Education to take immediate action
in the matter.

Carried.

Resolution No. 3 refers to the condition of the stove and
floor in the school house. I asked the Inspector, Mr.
Ferguson to recommend the purchase of a new stove and a
new floor laid some time ago. The stove is not safe to
use, and the floor is worn through in many places.

O. J. Silver.
Indian Agent.
The Council did not deal with the subject of a new pump or probably considerable repairs to the present one at the school on the reserve. I would suggest it being always kept in good working order and at least six tin pails always available and under the care of the teacher for it is the only protection we have in case of a fire.

O.J. Silver.
Indian Agent.
Res. No. 3.

Moved by Leslie McCue and seconded by Tom Porte and resolved that we paint the school and that we request the educational Dept. to purchase necessary paint and material, and also pay labour, it was further resolved that tenders for labour be received by the Indian Agent and Chief within one week.

Carried.

Last year when the Hall and Church were painted I suggested painting the school house as it has been some time since it was done and needs it badly.

Tenders have been received and awarded Tom Porte at $18.00 for labour only. 2½ gallons of paint at $4.00 per gal. $10.00; two brushes and sand paper about $1.25 - an approximate cost in all $30.00.

Department letter 10-1-9 dated April 21st gave permission to repair the school fence at a cost of $20.50 - we got the caretaker to do some repairs and if other requests are expending too much educational funds the school fence with present repairs might be left over for another year if necessary.

O.J. Silver,
Indian Agent.
No. 2.

Moved by Tom Porte and seconded by Leslie McCue and resolved that we repair the school roof immediately and that we request the Educational Dept to grant us the sum of one hundred dollars estimated cost of material and labour the material being lumber for sheeting, shingles and nails. It was further resolved that tenders for this labour be received by the Indian Agent and Chief within one week.

Carried.

The school house roof leaks in many places, on enquiry I learn that it will require about 9 M shingles and good cedar shingles are $5.60 per M. - $$50.40 requiring about 30 lbs nails, galvanized nails are 12¢ a lb.- $3.60. Ridge boards about $2.50. The delivery to the school will likely cost $5.00 and the tender received and accepted for the labour is $18.00- putting them on in all approximately $80.00. The cleaning up and piling them inside for kindling may cost a little more.

O.J. Silver,
Indian Agent.
GEORGINA ISLD. MINUTES OF COUNCIL MEETING HELD JUNE 12, 1939.

No. 4.

Moved by Tom Porte and seconded by Leslie McCue that we purchase an iron gate 3 feet 4 inches x 4 feet to be used on the fence at the public grounds.

Sutton West, June 16, 1939.

There is a gate needed at the school entrance as there is nothing left but part of the frame of the one there at present.

O.J. Silver,
Indian Agent.
GEORGIA ISLD. MINUTES OF COUNCIL MEETING HELD SEPTEMBER 18, 1939.

Res. No. 8.

Moved by Leslie McCue and seconded by Tom Porte and resolved that this council request the educational dept. to pay the sum of three dollars to Arthur Saleby for putting the school seats in and two dollars to Stewart McCue for the transportation from the beach to the school.

Carried.

Sutton West, Sept. 22, 1939.

The new school seats were taken to the Island on the 12th inst. The old seats removed and the new ones placed and fastened down by Arthur Saleby. The Council recommend him being paid $3.00 for his work and Stewart McCue being paid $2.00 for taking the seats from the beach to the school.

O. J. Silver,
Indian Agent.
MEMORANDUM:

THE DIRECTOR

I beg to submit the following report on my inspection of the Georgina and Snake Island Agency.

The one Day school on the reserve was visited on the 6th of September. There were 18 pupils present. Some families had not returned to the reserve for school opening.

The school building is in good condition, with the exception of the entrance steps which are badly worn and should be replaced. This could be done by an Indian for about $10.00.

The interior walls and ceiling should be painted; they are very dingy and depressing. The ceiling and walls three-quarter way up are metal-sheeted. The cost of material and labour would not exceed $75.00.

Thos. McGookin,
Inspector of Indian Agencies Ontario.
GEORGINA ISLD. MINUTES OF COUNCIL MEETING HELD JAN. 10, 1940.

The Council authorizes Ross Peters and J. Sam York to determine the cost of material and labour to wire the school for lights.

J. R. Ashquabe.

The Acting Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to the matter referred to by Mr. Arnold, Barrister, in his letter addressed to the Hon. A. B. Amesworth, I beg to say that on January 26, last, a request was received, signed on behalf of many of the parents on the Gibson reserve by the Chief, Napoleon Commandant, N. Ryerson Young, Superintendent of the Methodist Church and Thomas Whitebeans, the teacher, asking that school be held for part of the year in the school-house, which is situated on lot 11, in the 5th concession, and for the balance of the year in the church on lot 13, in the 6th concession, the distance between these two points being a little over a mile and a-half.

This matter was referred to the local superintendent for report, who, after making enquiries, recommended that the request be granted and that the school be held in the church from July 1 to Dec. 31, and from Jan. 2 to June 30 in the school-house, and this recommendation was approved, conditional on the manner in which the children attended.

On the 16th ult. a petition was received from certain Indians of the reserve, protesting against the new arrangement. These Indians were informed that, in view of the facts as presented to the Department, the arrangement would have to stand. Further protest was received on the 6th inst. from Simon Corinthe and Francis Decaire, asking for an investigation into this matter.
They were told in reply that, unless some good reasons could be shown to the contrary, no change in the present arrangement could be made. On the 24th inst., these same Indians gave their reasons for their protest, which was based on the distance that some of the children would have to walk to attend school in the church, and they asked that a government official be authorized to attend the council to be held on the 1st prox. to discuss the situation.

I find on referring to the old files in connection with the school on this reserve that, as far back as in 1892, the Indians petitioned to have the change made which has just been inaugurated, and Mr. Walton, who was then Indian Superintendent, reported that, while he was not sure that it would be advantageous to hold school for six months in the year in two different localities, he was of opinion that the church was the most centrally located place on the reserve for holding the school. The matter was allowed to stay in abeyance until the present time.

Upon referring to the plan of the Indian reserve in the township of Gibson, I find that locations have been issued for certain lots from the 1st to the 11th concessions, the bulk of which locations are taken up north of the 6th concession. The number of children of school age on the reserve is given as about 40, and if the children are in proportion to the locations tickets issued, more than half that number would come from above the 6th concession. The enrolment for last year varied from 18 to 22, with an average attendance of 10. Upon referring to the accompanying blue print you will see that no matter in which place the school is held some of the children will have a considerable distance to walk.
and as most of them come from north of the 6th concession
the larger number will benefit by having the school in

Your letter of the 21st inst., addressed to the Honourable Mr. Ayleworth, Minister of Justice, respecting the removal of the Gibson school from the school-house to the Methodist church has been transferred to this Department.

In connection with this matter I beg to say that the present arrangement for holding school six months in the year in the Methodist church and six months in the school-house was arrived at on representations made to the Department that a number of the younger children on the roll came from a settlement near the church and too far away to attend at the school-house, and that it would be only fair to give them an opportunity of obtaining some education.

There are about forty children of school age on this reserve, and, owing to the way the Indians

locations are scattered over the reserve, it would not be possible to place a school-house where they could all be within a reasonable walking distance. This being the fact, the Department decided to accede to the request of certain Indians to try the experiment of having the school conducted from July to January in the church and from January to June in the school-house. The school-house will have the longest school term, as the holidays will come out of the church end.

The Indians have been pressing for this change for the last fifteen years, and as it was impracticable to have two separate schools on the reserve, the Department sanctioned this arrangement, which should work successfully, if it received the co-operation of all the Indians. Nearly all the Indians protesting against this arrangement are Indians who have no children of school age. No such teacher could be secured for less than $450.00, and they had never had such a teacher. Miss Smellie had no certificate at all, simply a permit. This is the same as Miss Robbins. I might say Miss Robbins has proceed in High School very near to Junior leaving standard.

I should like very much to know if I am to retain Miss Robbins. If not, I suppose I shall have to compensate her in some way, for I have really engaged her knowing to difficulty of securing teachers. To have waited to have forwarded the application would have prevented the engagement.

In our town school after much advertising and offering $400.00 salary upon the receipt of the first application, the person was wired an engagement for fear she would accept another position.

Please let me hear early.

Yours sincerely,

Memo.

The teacher of the Gibson Indian school resigned in the early part of January, last, and on the 27th of that month Dr. Sutherland was written to and asked to try to secure the services of a competent teacher.

This action was taken by the Supt. without any authority. He is evidently unaware that the nomination of a teacher for this school rests with the Methodist Church, and in any event he exceeded his powers.

The last paragraph of Dr. Sutherland's letter intimates that the Department will probably consider Miss Forrest's appointment as only temporary. The question arises as to what extent the action of the Supt. has compromised the Department. I think we could hardly dispense with her services before, say, June 30, next. I would suggest that Dr. Sutherland be written to and asked to ascertain whether Mr. Snider's services would be available to take charge of the school after the summer holidays and, if so, notice then then be given Miss Forrest.

Affairs at this school have not been satisfactory for
some time and it would appear a pity to lose the opportunity of getting an experienced male teacher, who, being a married man, would in all probability be more permanent.

I may say that a degree of unpleasantness has sprung up between Mr. Wm Kendall and Mr. Keech. Mr. Kendall is the Methodist Missionary and is absent at present.

I enclose you the correspondence in the meantime. I have advice Miss Forrest to resign her position under the circumstances as it would be unpleasant for all concerned. Should she remain on I am in your obedient servant.

The Secretary

Ottawa, April 14, 1909.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

Mr. Supt. Macdonald has forwarded several letters in connection with the Gibson school. This is recognized as a Methodist school and a vacancy having occurred the Superintendent appointed a Miss Maud C. Forrest without consulting the Department or the Church, although the Department was in communication with the Rev. Dr. Sutherland in reference to securing the services of a competent teacher for this reserve.

Dr. Sutherland was advised of the situation and expressed his willingness that Miss Forrest should remain on till the end of the school year, June 30, next. This arrangement was apparently satisfactory.

The correspondence forwarded by the Supt. indicates that trouble has arisen between the teacher and the wife of the resident missionary, Rev. Mr. Kendall, which will most likely result in the teacher's resignation being sent in, necessitating the closing of the school or the employment of an uneducated Indian boy. The whole trouble on this reserve seems to be that the resident missionary is married to an Indian woman, who makes herself most officious and overbearing. Mr. Kendall, although not actively engaged in the school work, is nominally the teacher. He signs the returns and draws the salary. It is time that
anomalous state of affairs should end and that the offices of teacher and missionary should be separated.

There is nothing in the correspondence that would justify the Department in calling for Miss Forrest's resignation and rather than that the school should be closed it would be well to ask her to remain on till the end of the quarter and the Methodist Church should be requested to nominate a teacher whose time would be devoted to that work alone, to take charge after the summer holidays.

Martin Butler
Ottawa, April 30, 1909.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th inst., with enclosures, in reference to the Gibson school, and in reply I beg to say that the correspondence would not justify the Department in calling for Miss Forrest's resignation. In fact, it would be glad if she would remain in charge of the school at least till the end of the current quarter, and you will be good enough to advise her accordingly.

Your obedient Servant,

H.D. McLean

Secretary.

D.F. Macdonald, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Parry Sound, Ont.
My dear Sir,

In a communication just received from Rev. C. W. Watch, of Huntsville, who has the oversight of the Indian Mission at Gibson, he informs me that Miss Forrest, the teacher recently appointed, has given him a month's notice of her intention to leave the school. Knowing the disadvantage it would be to the school to be left even for a time without a teacher, Mr. Watch has asked Miss Forrest to continue teaching, if possible, till the end of the school year. In taking this course Mr. Watch has no intention whatever of interfering with the action of the Indian Agent, but is simply trying to meet an emergency that has arisen.

We are obtaining information wherever possible with the hope that in due time we may be able to submit a name to the Department that will be in all respects satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
General Secretary.
